1.title: Requirements
1.content: . | ADB (Android Debug Bridge) | MQDH (Meta Quest Developer Hub) | .

2.title: Instalation
2.content: . | To begin plugin the headset to your computer and run adb tcpip 5555 | Install the QuestSLAM application through MQDH | . On the first launch you will have to have the headset on to allow permissions . | Launch the app with adb shell am start -n "com.kirvilnet.QuestSLAM/com.unity3d.player.UnityPlayerGameActivity | .

3.title: Command Arguements
3.content: These need to be placed after a -e tag . | Arguement | Description | Default. | Example | Required | . | "ip" | ip of rosbridge | "0.0.0.0" | “10.7.1.10” | ✅ | . | "port" | port of rosbridge | "9090" | “9090” | ✅ | . | "id" | ID of the QuestSLAM instance. | "0" | “567” | ✅ | .

5.title: Developer account
5.content: . | Follow this guide to enable developer mode | Download the Meta Quest Developer Hub (MQDH) | .

6.title: Disable Gaurdian
6.content: . | Gaurdian must be disabled to prevent app interuptions and relilablity issues. | Navigate to Settings → Advanced → Experimental Settings → Enable Custom Settings | Turn OFF Physical Space Features, MTP Notification, and Link Auto Connect | .

7.title: Disable Bluetooth
7.content: . | Bluetooth can be disabled with adb shell svc bluetooth disable | .

9.title: Pick a ethernet adapter
9.content: Here is a list of working ethernet adapters that work with the quest 3/3s. All of these provide both power and ethernet conncetions to the headset . | Cable Matters 5-Port USB-C Hub On-The-Go | onn. 8-in-1 USB-C Adapter, USB 3.0 and 4K HDMI Compatible | Belkin Connect USB-C to Ethernet + Charge Adapter 100W | .

10.title: Pluging in
10.content: Plugin the adapter and connect the ethernet and power from a relilable poewer source . Wifi must be disabled to prevent conflicts with adb shell svc wifi disable .

11.title: Power Requirements
11.content: The internal quest battery provides around 2.5 hours of use . Power sources must be able to supply 5v at 3A to charge the headset while in use . This could be done in 2 ways . | USB Power bank | 5v regulator connected to the robots battery | POE to usbc adapter | .

12.title: Mounting
12.content: Mounting the Quest in an optimal location is important for the operation of the QuestSLAM application .

13.title: Mounts
13.content: There are a variety of mounts made by first robotics teams . | Mount by 3847 spectrum | This other one from printables | .

14.title: Mounting position
14.content: . | Mount the headset at least 12 inches (30cm) above the floor. | Make sure the headset has a clear view. | Make sure it will not be blocked by moving parts | .

15.title: Best Pratices
15.content: . | Cable Type: CAT5e or CAT6 Ethernet cable | Length: Ideally under 3 feet (1 meter) | Shielded: Recommended in high-EMI environments | Strain Relief: Consider right-angle connectors if space is limited | .

16.title: Device Setup
16.content: Before we can use the QuestSLAM app we have to configure the headset to optimize it for QuestSLAM .

17.title: Requirements
17.content: . | ROS2 Instalation | A LAN network (wireless or ethernet) | (optiona but reccomended) usb-c to LAN adapter | .

19.title: QuestSLAM
19.content: This project enables streaming of Quest3/3s tracking information over ROS Bridge for SLAM Mapping. This pose information can be used to localize a robot in 3 dimentional space while being light and cost effective. The sensors aboard the Quest3 and 3s have an accuracy of .

20.title: Key Features
20.content: . | Self-contained, rechargeable battery | Network based data transmission (wired and wireless) | Up to 120Hz tracking refresh rate | Built on Unity allowing for easy modification for special use cases | Powered by Qualcomm XR2G2 platform with multiple CPU/GPU cores, 8GB RAM, dedicated video hardware, and 128GB+ storage | .

21.title: How it works
21.content: QuestSLAM is built on the Quest Visual-Inertial Odometry (VIO) system allowing it to track in 3d space with high levels of accuracy. | Capture data (IMU, VIO, Accelerometer) | Process data and add corvaience | Convert Unity coordinates to ROS cooordinates | Generate ROS2 messages (Odometry, Battery%, Velocity, camera, tracking status, aprialtag position) | Send data over network (Ethernet or Wireless) | .

22.title: Current Features
22.content: . | Odometry messages over ROS bridge | Basic headset telemetry (Batter precentage) | Launch over ADB | .

23.title: Features to come
23.content: . | Streaming of video from onboard cameras | Aprial tag recognition and assigning a transform to it | intergration into nav stack | .

25.title: Intro
25.content: This covers all of the ros2 topics, services, and actions and their usage.

26.title: Topics
26.content: | Topic | Topic Type | Descriptions | . | QuestSLAM/"id"/battery_level | std_msgs/Float32 | battery level as a float 0-100. | . | QuestSLAM/"id"/camera | sensor_msgs/Image | Image stream from the left camera. | . | QuestSLAM/"id"/odom | nav_msgs/msg/Odometry | Location of the headset as an odometry message. | . | QuestSLAM/"id"/is_tracking | std_msgs/bool | Tracking status. | . | QuestSLAM/"id"/apriatags | ID of the QuestSLAM instance. | AprialTags as a transform. One transform per tag detected | .
